If the matter is security related, please disclose it privately via https://kubernetes.io/security/
-->


**What happened**:
I was writing a variant of clock.FakeClock, and noticed a couple of bugs in `func (f *fakeTimer) Stop()`.  Look at the pointer comparison in https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/blob/c7972d9a5e7f555371fec7a3237f08ebc1ae9d7c/staging/src/k8s.io/apimachinery/pkg/util/clock/clock.go#L298 --- the two pointers will never be equal, but the author clearly expected equality when `i` is the index of the fakeClockWaiter corresponding to the fakeTimer.  The two pointers will never be equal because one is a pointer into the fakeClock's `waiters` slice while the other pointer is to a field of the `fakeTimer`.  The consequence of this bug is that the Stop function is ineffective.

Also, https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/blob/c7972d9a5e7f555371fec7a3237f08ebc1ae9d7c/staging/src/k8s.io/apimachinery/pkg/util/clock/clock.go#L305 determines the returned value based on the original copy of the waiter, which --- being a copy --- did not get updated if/when the waiter fired.

Note also that clock_test.go does not exercise FakeClock::NewTimer at all.

**What you expected to happen**:
I expected FakeClock Timers to work properly.

**How to reproduce it (as minimally and precisely as possible)**:
Use the TestFakeTimer func introduced in #78808
